Literature Review: The exploration of virus-derived small RNAs (sRNAs) and microRNAs (miRNAs) has unveiled a complex layer of virus-host interactions that play pivotal roles in health and disease. miRNAs, short noncoding RNAs, are crucial regulators of gene expression, influencing induction, transcription, and translation processes. Viruses, particularly double-stranded DNA viruses, have evolved to encode their own miRNAs, known as virus-derived miRNAs (v-miRNAs), which are instrumental in modulating the host's immune response to favor viral persistence and replication. This literature review delves into the mechanisms by which v-miRNAs facilitate viral evasion of the host immune system, contribute to chronic latent infections, and their implications in chronic stress, inflammation, immunopathology, and disease. Furthermore, it highlights the advancements in viral RNA-based research, including in silico approaches for the functional characterization of v-miRNAs and other RNA types, which are paving the way for the identification of novel therapeutic targets to combat viral infections. The Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) serves as a prime example of a virus that utilizes v-miRNAs to manipulate host cell processes, illustrating the broader significance of v-miRNAs in viral pathogenesis. The integration of bioinformatics tools and viral RNA bioinformatics resources has significantly enhanced our understanding of v-miRNAs, enabling the prediction of their targets and the elucidation of their roles in virus-host interactions. This review underscores the importance of continued research into v-miRNAs and sRNAs, not only for their fundamental biological insights but also for their potential in therapeutic development against viral diseases.
